CatDescriptText: Morris Friedman, trainman, Pittsburgh, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 6, 1959, pg. 1 with question: "Do you think that racial prejudice is inherent or is it taught to children? If you believe that it is taught do you think that the teaching of it is increasing or diminishing?  If so, by whom do you think that it is taught?" answer reads: "I don't think that prejudice is inherent.  I think that it is acquired from friends with whom they associate.  In my opinion, it is decreasing.  I think that people are more open minded today and have a better understanding of their fellowmen [sic]."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Morris Friedman wearing plaid button down short sleeve collared shirt, head turned sideways, standing in front of ribbed metal wall
